title: 106_hr2674
content:
The "Palmetto Bend Conveyance Act" defines key terms like "Project," "Secretary," and "State" related to the Palmetto Bend Reclamation Project in Texas. The Secretary is required to convey all right, title, and interest in the Project to the State, excluding the mineral estate. If the conveyance is not completed within a specified timeframe, a report must be submitted to relevant committees. Upon conveyance of the Project to the State, the State must pay the Secretary the adjusted net present value of current repayment obligations, along with interest. This payment extinguishes the State's obligation under the Bureau of Reclamation Contract No. 14-06-500. Upon completion of conveyance, the State will assume full responsibility for operation, maintenance, and replacement of the Project. The State will also bear the cost of boundary surveys, title searches, appraisals, and other transaction costs. All funds paid by the State to the Secretary will be credited to the Reclamation Fund. SEC. 5. FUTURE MANAGEMENT. As a condition of conveyance, the State must agree to manage the Project for its original purposes, including providing water supply, conserving wildlife, and enhancing recreation. Management decisions regarding fish, wildlife, and recreation resources must be made according to an approved agreement between recipients of the Project and the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. The State must manage the Project for its original purposes, including water supply, wildlife conservation, and recreation, according to an approved agreement with the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. The United States will assign all surface use obligations to the State, including contracts, easements, permits, and license agreements. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT OF MINERAL ESTATE.

Mineral interests in the Project retained by the United States will be managed in accordance with Federal law without interfering with the Project's authorized purposes.

SEC. 7. LIABILITY.

The United States will not be liable for damages related to the Project post-conveyance, except for negligence prior to conveyance by the United States, its employees, agents, or contractors.

SEC. 8. FUTURE BENEFITS. After purchasing the Project, the State will not receive any benefits under Federal reclamation law.
